Award.AwardTitle: Weighing and measuring the Milky Way and other galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Robyn Sanderson is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at Columbia University and New York University. Outside the Galactic disk, where most stars including our Sun reside, most of our Galaxy's mass is in its roughly spherical halo of dark matter, invisible material only known to exist through its gravitational influence. Also out there are a handful of halo stars, including the scattered remains of smaller galaxies that entered the Milky Way's dark halo only to be ripped apart by its tidal forces. The structures left behind, called tidal streams, can be used to study the distribution of the Milky Way's dark matter. Each tidal stream is made up of stars that were once neighbors in the same small galaxy, and thus now follow similar paths as they orbit the Milky Way. This common origin gives us insight into the Galaxy's mass distribution, which determines the orbits of the stream's stars: only if we guess close to the true mass distribution do the computed orbits of stars in each stream cluster together around a common progenitor. Changes to the neighboring orbits of tidal stream stars could also provide evidence for smaller-scale dark matter structure: tiny dark matter clumps too small to hold galaxies, predicted by some theories of dark matter, would deflect the paths of stream stars in predictable ways. Dr. Sanderson will develop new tools to explore the structure of dark matter halos, particularly the Milky Way's, by studying their tidal streams. These tools use state-of-the-art methods, yet are based on fundamental concepts that kids learn in middle school: why stars shine, how we make and read maps, and how gravity works. To teach these core ideas and inspire middle schoolers' interest in science, Dr. Sanderson will develop portable science lessons for use in underserved New York City middle schools. The modules will use songs and movement the students produce themselves to introduce them to the "music of the spheres."

The work Dr. Sanderson will carry out as a fellow has three goals. First, she will expand a new method of inferring the Milky Way's mass distribution, which uses concepts borrowed from information theory to statistically analyze the clustering of halo stars in streams and thereby select the best fit for the Milky Way halo. This method will be applied to forthcoming data from the Gaia satellite, which will accurately measure complete positions and velocities for millions of stream stars in the Milky Way. Second, she will study the influence of small dark matter clumps on tidal streams, by predicting their effects on the orbits of the stream stars and determining which effects would be most diagnostic to observe. Finally, Dr. Sanderson will complete tests of a new tool to estimate the masses of galaxies outside our Milky Way, based on observations of a particular type of tidal stream known as a shell or umbrella. In these special cases we can understand the stream stars' orbits, and hence the mass of the host galaxy, even with only the limited information we can obtain for such distant stars. The information from these new strategies will allow Dr. Sanderson to compare the structures of galaxy halos, including our Milky Way's, to predictions based on different theories of dark matter. The images, movies, and computer simulations produced in her work will be incorporated into the middle school science lessons she will develop, to help educate and inspire a new generation of American scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The nature of dark matter, which makes up 85 percent of the mass in the Universe, is still one of the biggest mysteries in astrophysics more than 100 years since its existence was first suggested. Embarrassingly, we don't even really know how much dark matter there is in our own Galaxy, the Milky Way---there are many estimates that range over more than a factor of three. We also have very little idea how it is distributed around the Galaxy: we think it is concentrated around the Galaxy in a blob known as a dark matter "halo," but we do not know what the halo's shape is or how much dark matter is in small lumps versus a smooth distribution. Knowing this is difficult because dark matter is invisible except through its gravity, which influences the motions of the stars we can see. But it is also really important, since different theories for what dark matter is make different predictions about the properties of the Milky Way's dark matter halo, so measuring its properties gives us information about the nature of dark matter itself. This project explored ways to improve our knowledge of the Milky Way's dark matter content---and that of other galaxies---by studying stars that came into the galaxy as part of other, smaller galaxies. These stars are some of the best for mapping the dark matter since their orbits often take them far out into the Galaxy.

Specifically, this project:

  • developed implemented, and tested a new way to use data from the upcoming Gaia survey of the Galaxy to describe our Galaxy's dark matter distribution.
  • significantly advanced our ability to directly compare state-of-the-art simulations of Milky-Way-like galaxies with observations: both for surveys like Gaia where we can measure the properties of individual stars, and for observations of other galaxies where we see only the combined light from many stars.
  • critically evaluated different methods to separate stars that formed in a galaxy from those that were formed in another galaxy first, then merged together, both in our Galaxy and others.
  • developed tools and data sets to release to the scientific community for generating mock surveys of stars that can be analyzed in parallel with real data, both for validating different analysis techniques and for interpreting features seen in the real data.

The tools and strategies this project has developed will be applied to next-generation observations and surveys to obtain a far more accurate view of our Milky Way's dark matter halo, leading to new tests of theories of dark matter.

 

In addition to scientific research, this project contributed to new organizational infrastructure at several institutions for mentoring and professional development of researchers from underrepresented groups. The PI personally mentored seven students from underrepresented groups at the transition from undergraduate to graduate study during the project, five in her role as Assistant Director for Physical Sciences in the Columbia Bridge to the Ph.D. Program and three as scientific advisor on research related to the goals of this project. Of these, four will be continuing to graduate study and the outcome is pending for the other three. At the end of her role as Assistant Director, the PI helped hire a permanent program director during the transition of the Columbia Bridge program to full insitutional support. Later in the project, the PI also served as a consultant to Cal-Bridge, a relatively young bridge program based in Southern California, to transfer some of the experience of the 10-year-old Columbia program. She also served on the steering committee that established a new group to support women studying physics, math, and astronomy at Caltech over all career stages from undergrad to faculty, which now reaches about a hundred people with a full program of professional development, informal mentoring, and social events. Together these efforts have directly contributed to retaining at least four members of underrepresented groups in the sciences through to graduate school, have provided professional preparation to several dozen more such students, and have helped solidify insititutional support for several programs that seek a greater equity in access to scientific careers for all Americans.
